title: Paris Prosecutor Describes Morning St.-Denis Raid
content: At a news conference Wednesday, the prosecutor, François Molins, said the authorities had neutralized ”a new team of terrorists” that was ready to act.
content_expanded: At a news conference Wednesday, the prosecutor, François Molins, said the authorities had neutralized ”a new team of terrorists” that was ready to act.

title: A French Police Dog Dies During St.-Denis Raid
content: A French police dog killed during a counterterrorism raid outside Paris has, perhaps predictably enough, drawn outsize attention on social media, to the consternation of people still overcome with horror over the Paris attacks. The death of Diesel, who was 7, set off an outpouring of sympathy online. After the French police released a photo of the dog on Twitter — “Assault and explosive detection dogs: essential for missions led by RAID members,” they wrote — photos of Diesel were soon circulating widely with the hashtag #JeSuisChien, or “I am dog.” https://twitter.com/PNationale/status/666916020234383361 Some people expressed anger and dismay that one dead animal appeared to be attracting more attention than any of the 129 people who were killed in the attacks on Friday. Diesel was a Belgian Malinois, an athletic breed known for agility and tracking ability that is commonly used by military and police forces. She assisted RAID, an elite French police unit roughly equivalent to an American SWAT team.
content_expanded:
A French police dog killed during a counterterrorism raid outside Paris has, perhaps predictably enough, drawn outsize attention on social media, to the consternation of people still overcome with horror over the Paris attacks.

The death of Diesel, who was 7, set off an outpouring of sympathy online. After the French police released a photo of the dog on Twitter — “Assault and explosive detection dogs: essential for missions led by RAID members,” they wrote — photos of Diesel were soon circulating widely with the hashtag #JeSuisChien, or “I am dog.”

Les chiens d'assaut et de recherche d'explosifs: indispensables dans les missions des opérateurs du #RAID pic.twitter.com/vb5lGjnwjO

— Police Nationale (@PNationale) November 18, 2015

Some people expressed anger and dismay that one dead animal appeared to be attracting more attention than any of the 129 people who were killed in the attacks on Friday.

Diesel was a Belgian Malinois, an athletic breed known for agility and tracking ability that is commonly used by military and police forces. She assisted RAID, an elite French police unit roughly equivalent to an American SWAT team.

title: France Still Planning to Accept 30,000 Refugees, Hollande Says
content: [nytmedia id="100000004044765" crop="592" type="image"] France will keep its promise to take in 30,000 refugees over the next two years, President François Hollande said on Wednesday. But he said they would be checked thoroughly to make sure they do not pose a threat. “Our country has the duty to respect this commitment,” Mr. Hollande said, noting that those fleeing areas of Syria and Iraq controlled by the Islamic State were being “tormented” by the “very same people who are attacking us today.” Speaking at a meeting of the country’s mayors on Wednesday, Mr. Hollande said that France would “remain a country of freedoms.” Mr. Hollande asked Parliament on Monday for new legislation that would give the government more flexibility to conduct police raids without a warrant and place people under house arrest. He said he would seek court advice on broader surveillance powers. And he called for amendments to the constitution that would make it easier to impose exceptional security measures. The discovery of a document that purported to be a Syrian passport and that seemed to have been used by a migrant passing through Greece has raised alarms in Europe that the influx of refugees to the continent was bringing new threats with it. Speaking in Manila on Wednesday, President Obama cautioned against inflating fears of migrants and criticized Republicans for “political posturing” on the admission of Syrian refugees into the United States. [nytmedia id="100000004044623" crop="592" type="video" autostart="false"] “When candidates say we should not admit 3-year-old orphans, that’s political posturing,” the president said. “When individuals say we should have religious tests, and only Christians, proven Christians, should be allowed, that’s offensive and contrary to American values.” “We are not well served when, in response to a terrorist attack, we descend into fear and panic,” he said. “We don’t make good decisions if it’s based on hysteria or an exaggeration of risks.” Aurelien Breeden reported from Paris, and Michael D. Shear from Manila.
content_expanded:
France will keep its promise to take in 30,000 refugees over the next two years, President François Hollande said on Wednesday. But he said they would be checked thoroughly to make sure they do not pose a threat.

“Our country has the duty to respect this commitment,” Mr. Hollande said, noting that those fleeing areas of Syria and Iraq controlled by the Islamic State were being “tormented” by the “very same people who are attacking us today.”

Speaking at a meeting of the country’s mayors on Wednesday, Mr. Hollande said that France would “remain a country of freedoms.”

Mr. Hollande asked Parliament on Monday for new legislation that would give the government more flexibility to conduct police raids without a warrant and place people under house arrest. He said he would seek court advice on broader surveillance powers. And he called for amendments to the constitution that would make it easier to impose exceptional security measures.

The discovery of a document that purported to be a Syrian passport and that seemed to have been used by a migrant passing through Greece has raised alarms in Europe that the influx of refugees to the continent was bringing new threats with it.

Speaking in Manila on Wednesday, President Obama cautioned against inflating fears of migrants and criticized Republicans for “political posturing” on the admission of Syrian refugees into the United States.

“When candidates say we should not admit 3-year-old orphans, that’s political posturing,” the president said. “When individuals say we should have religious tests, and only Christians, proven Christians, should be allowed, that’s offensive and contrary to American values.”

“We are not well served when, in response to a terrorist attack, we descend into fear and panic,” he said. “We don’t make good decisions if it’s based on hysteria or an exaggeration of risks.”


Aurelien Breeden reported from Paris, and Michael D. Shear from Manila.

title: ISIS Shares Image of Explosive That It Says Brought Down Russian Jet
content: [nytmedia id="100000004044584" crop="592" type="image"] The Islamic State, which has claimed responsibility for the downing of a Russian passenger plane over the Sinai Peninsula last month, released an image that purports to show the improvised explosive device used to kill all 224 people aboard the flight from Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt. In the latest issue of Dabiq, the Islamic State's glossy online magazine, first disseminated through Telegram, an encrypted messaging app, a picture shows what ISIS says were the components of an IED: A Gold Schweppes Pineapple tonic water can and two devices containing wires that appear to be the detonator and the switch. It includes a caption that says, “EXCLUSIVE – Image of the IED used to bring down the Russian airliner.” The veracity of the claim, and whether or not the specific device shown was used in the attack, could not immediately be determined. American and Russian officials have said that the debris from the plane suggests that there was a bomb on board. The accompanying article in the ISIS magazine says that Russia’s “arrogance” in bombing Syria prompted their operatives in the Sinai Peninsula to change their plan from blowing up a plane from one of the countries participating in the American-backed coalition against ISIS to attacking a Russian airliner. “It was a rash decision of arrogance from Russia,” the article says. “And so after having discovered a way to compromise the security at the Sharm el Sheikh International Airport and resolving to bring down a plane belonging to a nation in the American-led Western coalition against the Islamic State, the target was changed to a Russian plane. A bomb was smuggled onto the airplane, leading to the deaths of 219 Russians and 5 other crusaders only a month after Russia’s thoughtless decision.” As for the deadly attacks in France, the ISIS magazine says that the terrorist group had not forgotten that French airstrikes against Islamic State militants began on Sept. 19, 2014, in Iraq. And the article said that the leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi had vowed revenge. “Thus the Islamic State dispatched its brave knights to wage war,” the article says. “The eight knights brought Paris down on its knees, after years of French conceit in the face of Islam.” The issue did not provide any further details in how the Paris attacks were carried out. The cover of the English-language magazine shows emergency workers in Paris, and the title "Just Terror." https://twitter.com/_davidthomson/status/666993046991540225 The image of the device recalls the sort of "liquid bomb" three British men were planning to use in 2006 to blow up flights over the Atlantic. They were convicted in 2009 of planning to drain plastic soft-drink bottles with syringes and refill them with concentrated hydrogen peroxide, a bleaching agent also used as a propellant for rockets. That the bomb shown in the ISIS magazine seemed to include a switch on the detonator could raise the possibility that it might have been triggered by a bomber among the passengers. Rukmini Callimachi reported from Paris, and Robert Mackey from New York.
content_expanded:
The Islamic State, which has claimed responsibility for the downing of a Russian passenger plane over the Sinai Peninsula last month, released an image that purports to show the improvised explosive device used to kill all 224 people aboard the flight from Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt.

In the latest issue of Dabiq, the Islamic State’s glossy online magazine, first disseminated through Telegram, an encrypted messaging app, a picture shows what ISIS says were the components of an IED: A Gold Schweppes Pineapple tonic water can and two devices containing wires that appear to be the detonator and the switch.

It includes a caption that says, “EXCLUSIVE – Image of the IED used to bring down the Russian airliner.”

The veracity of the claim, and whether or not the specific device shown was used in the attack, could not immediately be determined. American and Russian officials have said that the debris from the plane suggests that there was a bomb on board.

The accompanying article in the ISIS magazine says that Russia’s “arrogance” in bombing Syria prompted their operatives in the Sinai Peninsula to change their plan from blowing up a plane from one of the countries participating in the American-backed coalition against ISIS to attacking a Russian airliner.

“It was a rash decision of arrogance from Russia,” the article says. “And so after having discovered a way to compromise the security at the Sharm el Sheikh International Airport and resolving to bring down a plane belonging to a nation in the American-led Western coalition against the Islamic State, the target was changed to a Russian plane. A bomb was smuggled onto the airplane, leading to the deaths of 219 Russians and 5 other crusaders only a month after Russia’s thoughtless decision.”

As for the deadly attacks in France, the ISIS magazine says that the terrorist group had not forgotten that French airstrikes against Islamic State militants began on Sept. 19, 2014, in Iraq. And the article said that the leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi had vowed revenge.

“Thus the Islamic State dispatched its brave knights to wage war,” the article says. “The eight knights brought Paris down on its knees, after years of French conceit in the face of Islam.”

The issue did not provide any further details in how the Paris attacks were carried out.

The cover of the English-language magazine shows emergency workers in Paris, and the title “Just Terror.”

L'Etat islamique diffuse le 12ème numéro de sa revue anglophone "Dabiq". En "Une", les attentats de Paris pic.twitter.com/VDPkzWQepH

— David Thomson (@_DavidThomson) November 18, 2015

The image of the device recalls the sort of “liquid bomb” three British men were planning to use in 2006 to blow up flights over the Atlantic. They were convicted in 2009 of planning to drain plastic soft-drink bottles with syringes and refill them with concentrated hydrogen peroxide, a bleaching agent also used as a propellant for rockets.

That the bomb shown in the ISIS magazine seemed to include a switch on the detonator could raise the possibility that it might have been triggered by a bomber among the passengers.

Rukmini Callimachi reported from Paris, and Robert Mackey from New York.

title: Eagles of Death Metal Members Say They Are ‘Horrified’
content: Ben Sisario notes that Eagles of Death Metal, the band that was playing when the Bataclan was attacked on Friday, has released a statement on social media saying its members were horrified at the attacks, and mourning associates who were killed at the concert venue. The band said it had suspended its shows. https://twitter.com/EODMofficial/status/667008715011129344 More from Mr. Sisario: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/19/arts/music/eagles-of-death-metal-make-first-statement-since-paris-attacks.html
content_expanded:
Ben Sisario notes that Eagles of Death Metal, the band that was playing when the Bataclan was attacked on Friday, has released a statement on social media saying its members were horrified at the attacks, and mourning associates who were killed at the concert venue. The band said it had suspended its shows.

pic.twitter.com/YxuCIbRI05

— EaglesOfDeathMetal (@EODMofficial) November 18, 2015

More from Mr. Sisario:

Eagles of Death Metal Make First Statement on Paris Attacks

By BEN SISARIO

The band, which was headlining at the Bataclan on Friday when gunmen stormed the venue, said on Facebook that members were still trying to process what happened.

title: ISIS Claims to Have Executed Two Hostages
content: [nytmedia id="100000004044560" crop="190" type="image"] In the new issue of its online magazine, the Islamic State claims to have executed two hostages. The two hostages were identified as a Chinese citizen, Fan Jinghui, and a Norwegian, Ole Johan Grimsgaard-Ofstad. The article describes their executions and say that they were “abandoned by the kafir (disbeliever) nations and organizations,” a phrase that ISIS has used in the past to mean that the captives' governments refused to pay a ransom for their release. According to SITE Intelligence, which tracks jihadist propaganda, both the captives were shown in the issue of Dabiq, the ISIS magazine, that was released in September. Around the same time, the jihadists used Telegram, an encrypted messaging app, to release information on how to pay the ransoms. China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has said little about Mr. Fan’s kidnapping when it was first revealed, only declaring that the government opposes violence against civilians. There was no immediate comment from the Chinese government when reports of Mr. Fan’s death first emerged. Mr. Fan, 50, was once a middle-school teacher in Beijing who called himself a “wanderer.” Mr. Grimsgaard-Ofstad, 48, disappeared in January. Militants for the Islamic State are known to still be holding at least one foreign woman whose nationality and identity are being withheld out of fears for her security, as well as a Briton, John Cantlie. Mr. Cantlie, a freelance journalist, was on assignment in Syria and traveling with an American journalist, James Foley, when the two were kidnapped on Nov. 22, 2012. Mr. Cantlie and the woman are the last of the group held with Mr. Foley to still be alive. The magazine includes an article said to be written by Mr. Cantlie. The last time an article supposedly written by Mr. Cantlie was included in Dabiq was in May, prompting speculation that he had been executed.
content_expanded:
In the new issue of its online magazine, the Islamic State claims to have executed two hostages.

The two hostages were identified as a Chinese citizen, Fan Jinghui, and a Norwegian, Ole Johan Grimsgaard-Ofstad. The article describes their executions and say that they were “abandoned by the kafir (disbeliever) nations and organizations,” a phrase that ISIS has used in the past to mean that the captives’ governments refused to pay a ransom for their release.

According to SITE Intelligence, which tracks jihadist propaganda, both the captives were shown in the issue of Dabiq, the ISIS magazine, that was released in September. Around the same time, the jihadists used Telegram, an encrypted messaging app, to release information on how to pay the ransoms.

China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has said little about Mr. Fan’s kidnapping when it was first revealed, only declaring that the government opposes violence against civilians.

There was no immediate comment from the Chinese government when reports of Mr. Fan’s death first emerged.

Mr. Fan, 50, was once a middle-school teacher in Beijing who called himself a “wanderer.”

Mr. Grimsgaard-Ofstad, 48, disappeared in January.

Militants for the Islamic State are known to still be holding at least one foreign woman whose nationality and identity are being withheld out of fears for her security, as well as a Briton, John Cantlie.

Mr. Cantlie, a freelance journalist, was on assignment in Syria and traveling with an American journalist, James Foley, when the two were kidnapped on Nov. 22, 2012. Mr. Cantlie and the woman are the last of the group held with Mr. Foley to still be alive.

The magazine includes an article said to be written by Mr. Cantlie. The last time an article supposedly written by Mr. Cantlie was included in Dabiq was in May, prompting speculation that he had been executed.

title: Recap: Wednesday’s Developments in France
content:
As the French authorities pursue suspects and try to piece together what happened in the terrorist attacks that killed at least 129 people in Paris on Friday, here are the major developments so far today:
  • The police stormed an apartment in St.-Denis, a northern Paris suburb, before dawn. One of the apartment's occupants, a woman, blew herself up with a suicide vest, and another man was shot and killed during the raid, the police said. Seven people were arrested.
  • The police said they met fierce resistance. The neighborhood was rocked by explosions and gunfire in the predawn hours.
  • The raid was intended to capture Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a Belgian man suspected of organizing the attacks in Paris. For days the authorities said they believed he was in Syria, but French officials said on Tuesday they had reason to believe he might still be in Paris.
  • It was not immediately known whether Mr. Abaaoud was arrested,  was killed in the raid or was still at large. The police have not yet released names of any of those who were killed or detained on Tuesday.
  • The French authorities said they had identified all 129 people killed in the attacks on Friday.
  • A discarded mobile phone was found in a trash can near the Bataclan concert hall, the site of the deadliest attack on Friday, and the police believe it was used by one of the attackers. They said a text message was found on the phone saying "On est parti on commence," which means "We are starting."
  • The police continued to search for another person linked with Friday’s attack, Salah Abdeslam. He rented a car that was used to transport some of the gunmen in the Paris rampage, and served time in prison in Brussels at the same time as Mr. Abaaoud. His brother Ibrahim was one of the suicide bombers on Friday.
content_expanded:
As the French authorities pursue suspects and try to piece together what happened in the terrorist attacks that killed at least 129 people in Paris on Friday, here are the major developments so far today:

  • The police stormed an apartment in St.-Denis, a northern Paris suburb, before dawn. One of the apartment’s occupants, a woman, blew herself up with a suicide vest, and another man was shot and killed during the raid, the police said. Seven people were arrested.
  • The police said they met fierce resistance. The neighborhood was rocked by explosions and gunfire in the predawn hours.
  • The raid was intended to capture Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a Belgian man suspected of organizing the attacks in Paris. For days the authorities said they believed he was in Syria, but French officials said on Tuesday they had reason to believe he might still be in Paris.
  • It was not immediately known whether Mr. Abaaoud was arrested,  was killed in the raid or was still at large. The police have not yet released names of any of those who were killed or detained on Tuesday.
  • The French authorities said they had identified all 129 people killed in the attacks on Friday.
  • A discarded mobile phone was found in a trash can near the Bataclan concert hall, the site of the deadliest attack on Friday, and the police believe it was used by one of the attackers. They said a text message was found on the phone saying “On est parti on commence,” which means “We are starting.”
  • The police continued to search for another person linked with Friday’s attack, Salah Abdeslam. He rented a car that was used to transport some of the gunmen in the Paris rampage, and served time in prison in Brussels at the same time as Mr. Abaaoud. His brother Ibrahim was one of the suicide bombers on Friday.

title: Awakening to a Raid Upstairs, and Explosions
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004044561" crop="592" type="image"] A young woman who said she lives directly below the apartment in St.-Denis that was stormed by the French authorities early Wednesday described what she heard and saw in interviews with the French radio broadcaster France Info and Paris Match. The woman, who gave her name as Sabrine, said she was awakened at about 4 a.m. by the noise of the raid above her.
The first thing I heard was an explosion, ‘paaahh’ — that’s what woke me up with my son. The first thing I did was take my son and lie down on the floor. When you see bullets and you have a baby — I was in a panic, I was trembling. And I didn’t even know if they were the police. I didn’t believe them when they said, ‘This is the police.’ There were explosions. One could really feel the building shake. There were men upstairs who were running; one could hear them shouting ‘No, no, no, don’t shoot!’
The interviewer asked if it was the suspects’ voices that she heard.
Yes, they were just above me. They were talking, and the police were, too. They were saying, ‘Reload, reload, hurry up!’ I was shouting ‘Please, please, if you are from the police, help me!’
The building was badly damaged by explosions during the raid, she said.
The entire building shook. The staircases no longer look like anything. There is a large hole in my ceiling, there were bullet holes near the door, and near my window — horrible! And it really smelled. I couldn’t move — I was afraid I would be shot at with my son. I was trying to hide. With every new explosion, he was tearing at my skin with his nails.
Police officers soon came to secure her floor of the building and evacuate residents, she said.
They pushed us into the bedroom. Then, as soon as it was possible, they let us outside one by one, and we ran.
content_expanded:
A young woman who said she lives directly below the apartment in St.-Denis that was stormed by the French authorities early Wednesday described what she heard and saw in interviews with the French radio broadcaster France Info and Paris Match. The woman, who gave her name as Sabrine, said she was awakened at about 4 a.m. by the noise of the raid above her.

The first thing I heard was an explosion, ‘paaahh’ — that’s what woke me up with my son. The first thing I did was take my son and lie down on the floor.

When you see bullets and you have a baby — I was in a panic, I was trembling. And I didn’t even know if they were the police. I didn’t believe them when they said, ‘This is the police.’

There were explosions. One could really feel the building shake. There were men upstairs who were running; one could hear them shouting ‘No, no, no, don’t shoot!’

The interviewer asked if it was the suspects’ voices that she heard.

Yes, they were just above me. They were talking, and the police were, too. They were saying, ‘Reload, reload, hurry up!’

I was shouting ‘Please, please, if you are from the police, help me!’

The building was badly damaged by explosions during the raid, she said.

The entire building shook. The staircases no longer look like anything. There is a large hole in my ceiling, there were bullet holes near the door, and near my window — horrible! And it really smelled.

I couldn’t move — I was afraid I would be shot at with my son. I was trying to hide. With every new explosion, he was tearing at my skin with his nails.

Police officers soon came to secure her floor of the building and evacuate residents, she said.

They pushed us into the bedroom. Then, as soon as it was possible, they let us outside one by one, and we ran.

title: Hollande Plans to Discuss ‘Large Coalition’ With Obama and Putin
content: [nytmedia id="100000004044290" crop="592" type="image"] President François Hollande of France said Wednesday that he would travel to Washington on Tuesday to meet with President Barack Obama and then to Moscow two days later to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to discuss the formation of “a large coalition” to act “decisively” against the Islamic State. Speaking to a conference of French mayors hours after the police stormed the Paris suburb of St. Denis in a bid to find Abdelhamid Abaaoud, the Belgian man suspected of coordinating the Paris terrorist attacks last week, Mr. Hollande said the raid, during which a woman detonated an explosive vest, “confirms that we are at war.” “Daesh has financial and oil resources, and has created young radical Islamists through complicity in Europe and within our own country,” he told the gathering, using an Arabic acronym for the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. “Their attacks bloodied Paris and St.-Denis,” he added, “but it is the entire country that has been attacked.” The White House issued a statement late Tuesday stating that Mr. Hollande would meet with Mr. Obama in the Oval Office on Nov. 24. The two men will “consult and coordinate our efforts to assist France's investigations into the attacks, and discuss further coordination as part of the 65-member counter-ISIL coalition.”
content_expanded:
President François Hollande of France said Wednesday that he would travel to Washington on Tuesday to meet with President Barack Obama and then to Moscow two days later to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to discuss the formation of “a large coalition” to act “decisively” against the Islamic State.

Speaking to a conference of French mayors hours after the police stormed the Paris suburb of St. Denis in a bid to find Abdelhamid Abaaoud, the Belgian man suspected of coordinating the Paris terrorist attacks last week, Mr. Hollande said the raid, during which a woman detonated an explosive vest, “confirms that we are at war.”

“Daesh has financial and oil resources, and has created young radical Islamists through complicity in Europe and within our own country,” he told the gathering, using an Arabic acronym for the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

“Their attacks bloodied Paris and St.-Denis,” he added, “but it is the entire country that has been attacked.”

The White House issued a statement late Tuesday stating that Mr. Hollande would meet with Mr. Obama in the Oval Office on Nov. 24. The two men will “consult and coordinate our efforts to assist France’s investigations into the attacks, and discuss further coordination as part of the 65-member counter-ISIL coalition.”

title: Details for Bataclan Attack Found on Cellphone in Paris Trash Can
content:
A cellphone that could belong to one of the attackers was found in a trash can near the Bataclan concert hall in Paris, according to the French publications Le Monde and Mediapart.

Investigators found a detailed plan of the Bataclan assault and a text message sent at 9:42 p.m. on Friday that read, "On est parti on commence." This can be translated as "Here we go, we're starting," or, more literally, "We have left, we're starting."

The identities of the sender and the recipient of the text message remained unclear.

Investigators told Le Monde that geolocation services on the phone led them to one of the places the attackers were last seen, in the Paris suburb of Alfortville.
content_expanded:
A cellphone that could belong to one of the attackers was found in a trash can near the Bataclan concert hall in Paris, according to the French publications Le Monde and Mediapart.

Investigators found a detailed plan of the Bataclan assault and a text message sent at 9:42 p.m. on Friday that read, “On est parti on commence.” This can be translated as “Here we go, we’re starting,” or, more literally, “We have left, we’re starting.”

The identities of the sender and the recipient of the text message remained unclear.

Investigators told Le Monde that geolocation services on the phone led them to one of the places the attackers were last seen, in the Paris suburb of Alfortville.
